Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of Interspinous Process Devices vs. Decompressive Surgery for Lumbar Stenosis

Background: Standalone interspinous process devices (IPDs) for degenerative lumbar spinal stenosis with neurogenic intermittent claudication (NIC) have shown mixed results. This study aimed to evaluate the safety and noninferiority of a minimally invasive percutaneous IPD compared to standalone decompressive surgery (SDS).

Methods: This multicenter, international, open-label, randomised controlled trial enrolled 163 patients from 19 sites across 10 countries. Participants were randomised 1:1 to IPD or SDS, with randomisation implemented via an electronic data capture system using blinded blocks. The primary outcome was the mean percentage change in Zurich Claudication Questionnaire (ZCQ) physical function from baseline to 12 months. The study was registered at ClinicalTrials.gov (NCT00905359) and funded by Medtronic Spinal and Biologics.

Results: At 12 months, both groups showed significant improvement in ZCQ physical function (IPD: −32.3 ± 32.1, SDS: −37.5 ± 22.8, both P < .001). IPD was not significantly noninferior to SDS at 12 months (P = .172) but was at 24 months (P = .005). Reoperations occurred in 18.2% of IPD and 9.3% of SDS patients. Adverse events were similar between groups.

Interpretation: IPD and SDS achieved similar symptom relief in selected patients, but IPD had a higher reoperation rate. The study confirms findings from three recent RCTs.
